raw_text:
Aviation firms eye booming India
 
 India's defence minister has opened the country's Aero India 2005 air show with an invitation for global aerospace firms to outsource jobs to the nation.
 
 Pranab Mukherjee said such companies could take advantage of India's highly skilled workers and low wages. More than 240 civil and military aerospace firms from 31 countries are attending the show. Analysts said India could spend up to $35bn (£18.8bn) in the aviation market over the next 20 years. Giants such Boeing and Airbus - on the civil aviation front - as well as Lockheed Martin and France's Snecma - on the military side - are some of the firms attending the show. "There is tremendous scope for outsourcing from India in areas where the companies are competitive," said Mr Mukerjee. "We are keen to welcome international collaborations that are in conformity with our national goals."
 
 Lockheed said it had signed an agreement with state-owned Hindustan Aeronautics (HAL) to share information on the P-3 Orion maritime surveillance aircraft.
 
 In fact, the Indian Armed Force is considering the buying of used P-3 Orion as well as F-16 fighter jets from Lockheed. The US military industry has show a strong interest to open a link with India, now that relations between the two countries have improved a lot. In fact, it is the first time the US Air Force will attend the air show since sanctions imposed in 1998 after India's nuclear tests were lifted. But the Indian Air Force is also considering proposals from other foreign firms such as France's Dassault Aviation, Sweden's Saab and Russia's Mikoyan-Gurevich. Meanwhile, France's Snecma has also said it plans a joint venture with HAL to make engine parts, with an initial investment of $6.5m.
 
 On the civilian front, Boeing announced a deal with India's HCL Technologies to develop a platform for the flight test system of its 787 Dreamliner aircraft. The US company also said it had agreed with a new Indian budget airline the sale of 10 737-800 planes for $630m. The airline, SpiceJet, will also have the option to acquire 10 more aircraft. Airbus has also recently signed fresh deals with two Indian airlines - Air Deccan and Kingfisher. In addition, the European company has plans to open a training centre in India. Meanwhile, flag carrier Air India is considering to buy 50 new aircraft from either Boeing or Airbus. "No other market is going to see the growth that will be seen here in the coming years," said Dinesh Keskar, senior vice president Boeing.
llama3.2:1b: India's defence minister Pranab Mukherjee has invited global aerospace firms to outsource jobs in the country. The Indian Armed Force is considering buying used P-3 Orion and F-16 fighter jets from Lockheed Martin, while also looking at other foreign companies such as France's Dassault Aviation and Russia's Mikoyan-Gurevich.
llama3.2:3b: India's defence minister invites global aerospace firms to outsource jobs to India due to highly skilled workers and low wages. Over 240 firms from 31 countries attend Aero India 2005, including Boeing, Airbus, Lockheed Martin, and Snecma. India may spend up to $35bn in the aviation market over 20 years.
gemma2:2b: India's Aero India air show attracted many aerospace firms, with Indian Defense Minister inviting international companies to leverage its skilled workforce and low wages for outsourcing opportunities.  Giants such as Boeing, Airbus, Lockheed Martin, and Snecma are attending the show, discussing collaborations on military projects like P-3 Orion aircraft, fighter jets, and engine parts.  Civil aviation deals include Boeing's partnership with HCL Technologies for the 787 Dreamliner, sales of Boeing and Airbus planes to Indian airlines, and plans by Air India to purchase new aircraft. The market is expected to grow rapidly in India over the next two decades.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Aviation firms are eyeing large investment opportunities in India due to its skilled workforce and low cost of living, including companies such as Boeing, Airbus, Lockheed Martin, and France's Snecma. Indian firms like Hindustan Aeronautics have also shown interest in buying used aircraft and selling them to multinational aerospace companies for the potential $35 billion market over the next 20 years. Other international aerospace firms are also considering similar deals with India.
qwen2.5:1.5b: India's military and defense industries are attracting foreign firms for outsourcing jobs due to skilled labor and lower wages. Major aerospace companies like Boeing and Airbus have agreements with Indian firms to sell aircraft and engine parts. The Indian Air Force is exploring partnerships with other countries including France, Sweden, Russia, and Dassault Aviation.
qwen2.5:3b: India's Aero India 2005 air show attracts global aerospace firms with offers of outsourcing jobs due to skilled workers and low wages. The Indian Armed Forces are considering purchasing used P-3 Orion and F-16 fighter jets from Lockheed Martin. In the civilian sector, Boeing has signed a deal with HCL Technologies for the Dreamliner aircraft platform development and sold 10 737-800 planes to SpiceJet worth $630m. Airbus also signed deals with Indian airlines Air Deccan and Kingfisher. Meanwhile, France's Snecma plans a joint venture with HAL for engine parts production. Analysts estimate India could spend up to $35bn on the aviation market over the next 20 years.

Air India is also looking to buy 50 planes from Boeing or Airbus. Dinesh Keskar stated that no other market will see growth as significant in the coming years.

In addition, international collaboration agreements have been signed between the Indian Armed Force and American companies including Lockheed Martin to share information on the P-3 Orion surveillance aircraft, F-16 fighter jets, and 787 Dreamliner aircraft. While France's Dassault Avionics has also expressed interest in a joint venture with HAL to make engine parts. Meanwhile, Boeing announced a partnership with HCL Technologies to develop a platform for flight test systems of its Dreamliner aircraft, and a $630m deal with Spicejet for 10 737-800 planes. Airbus has also signed fresh deals with Indian airlines including Kingfisher Airlines to have the option to acquire more planes. The country's flag carrier, Air India, is considering buying up to 50 new aircraft from either Boeing or Airbus.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
India's Defense Minister Pranab Mukherjee has invited global aerospace firms to outsource jobs to India, highlighting the country's skilled workforce and low wages. Over 240 civil and military aerospace companies from 31 nations are attending Aero India 2005 in Bangalore. Analysts project India could invest up to $35 billion in aviation over the next two decades, with major players like Boeing and Airbus on the civilian front and Lockheed Martin, Snecma, Dassault Aviation, Saab, and Mikoyan-Gurevich on the military side.

Lockheed has signed an agreement with HAL to share P-3 Orion maritime surveillance data, and India is considering buying used P-3 Orions and F-16 fighter jets from Lockheed. The US Air Force will attend the air show for the first time since 1998 due to improved relations between the two countries. Other foreign firms like Dassault Aviation, Saab, and Mikoyan-Gurevich are also expressing interest in India's market.

On the civilian side, Boeing has partnered with HCL Technologies for 787 Dreamliner flight test system development and will sell 10 737-800 planes to SpiceJet, with potential for more. Airbus has recently signed deals with Air Deccan and Kingfisher, plans to open a training center in India, and is considering a large purchase of new aircraft by Air India from Boeing or Airbus. Boeing's Dinesh Keskar emphasizes India's potential for significant aviation growth.
